text: How does chat services send read notification data to the user?  Data payload on a push notification?  Collapsible?  And by the way ... Does Whatsapp use their own push notification platform or do they use FCM/APNS/WPNS/etc?  What about Telegram for that matter?
<@U2RKCC8H4> whether or not to show stuff when offline depends on the app and you should be able to answer that for yourself or ask your users.
We also don't know without looking it up what WhatsApp and others use for push notifications, best to also look that up yourself.

<@U061HDV96> I would let users access what is already on the device even when they don't have a network connection.  Think of Telegram (because it is open source) - you expect to see your old messages even when you don't have a connection.  About how they receive/update read notifications I will go look at the source of Telegram but it is daunting trying to find anything in there (I actually started looking at it)
About my other question - I'm looking for some best practices.

If the user is in the app, looking at old stuff, and a push notification comes through, and the app realises that the session is expired .... Or something like that.  The user might have "killed all sessions" from the web portal so when the app tries to sync the updates it needs to log in.  It just seems odd to me to ask for sign in in the middle of a user using an app, as opposed to when a user opens up the app to start working.
